**Obtaining a certified copy of your grandmother's Portuguese passport or ID card:**
To get a certified copy of your grandmother's Portuguese passport or ID card, you'll need to contact the relevant Portuguese authority. Here's a step-by-step guide to help you navigate the process:

1. **Contact the Portuguese Institute of Registries and Notaries (IRN):**
The IRN (Instituto dos Registos e do Notariado) is the central authority responsible for issuing certified copies of Portuguese documents. You can reach out to them directly to request a certified copy of your grandmother's passport or ID card.

**IRN Contact Information:**

* Website: [www.irn.mj.pt](http://www.irn.mj.pt)
* Phone: +351 21 881 10 00 (international) or 11 881 10 00 (from Portugal)
* Email: [irn@irn.mj.pt](mailto:irn@irn.mj.pt)

2. **Provide required information:**
When contacting the IRN, provide the following information:

* Your grandmother's full name and date of birth
* Her Portuguese citizen number (if known)
* The type of document you're requesting (passport or ID card)
* The time period when the document was issued (approximate year or decade)
* Your relationship to your grandmother (grandchild)

3. **Request a certified copy:**
The IRN will guide you through the process of requesting a certified copy of the document. They may ask you to fill out a form or provide additional information.

4. **Pay the required fee:**
You'll need to pay a fee for the certified copy, which will be specified by the IRN.

5. **Wait for the document:**
The IRN will send the certified copy of your grandmother's passport or ID card to you or your grandmother, depending on the arrangement you made.

**Alternative option:**

* If you're having difficulty contacting the IRN or need assistance, you can also reach out to the Portuguese embassy or consulate in your country. They may be able to provide guidance or help facilitate the process.

**Tips:**

* Be prepared to provide detailed information and documentation to support your request.
* The process may take some time, so plan ahead and allow for delays.
* If your grandmother is no longer alive, you may need to provide proof of her passing, such as a death certificate, to obtain the certified copy.

By following these steps, you should be able to obtain a certified copy of your grandmother's Portuguese passport or ID card, which will help support your application for Portuguese citizenship.
